segment.source: USMT Best Practices (Windows 10)
segment.target: USMT Best Practices (Windows 10)

segment.source: USMT Best Practices
segment.target: USMT Best Practices

segment.source: USMT Best Practices
segment.target: USMT Best Practices

segment.source: This topic discusses general and security-related best practices when using User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0.
segment.target: This topic discusses general and security-related best practices when using User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0.

segment.source: General Best Practices
segment.target: General Best Practices

segment.source: Install applications before running the LoadState tool
segment.target: Install applications before running the LoadState tool

segment.source: Though it is not always essential, it is best practice to install all applications on the destination computer before restoring the user state.
segment.target: Though it is not always essential, it is best practice to install all applications on the destination computer before restoring the user state.

segment.source: This helps ensure that migrated settings are preserved.
segment.target: This helps ensure that migrated settings are preserved.

segment.source: Do not use MigUser.xml and MigDocs.xml together
segment.target: Do not use MigUser.xml and MigDocs.xml together

segment.source: If you use both .xml files, some migrated files may be duplicated if conflicting instructions are given about target locations.
segment.target: If you use both .xml files, some migrated files may be duplicated if conflicting instructions are given about target locations.

segment.source: You can use the /genmigxml command-line option to determine which files will be included in your migration, and to determine if any modifications are necessary.
segment.target: You can use the /genmigxml command-line option to determine which files will be included in your migration, and to determine if any modifications are necessary.

segment.source: For more information, see Identify File Types, Files, and Folders.
segment.target: For more information, see Identify File Types, Files, and Folders.

segment.source: Use MigDocs.xml for a better migration experience
segment.target: Use MigDocs.xml for a better migration experience

segment.source: If your data set is unknown or if many files are stored outside of the standard user-profile folders, the MigDocs.xml file is a better choice than the MigUser.xml file, because the MigDocs.xml file will gather a broader scope of data.
segment.target: If your data set is unknown or if many files are stored outside of the standard user-profile folders, the MigDocs.xml file is a better choice than the MigUser.xml file, because the MigDocs.xml file will gather a broader scope of data.

segment.source: The MigDocs.xml file migrates folders of data based on location, and on registered file type by querying the registry for registered application extensions.
segment.target: The MigDocs.xml file migrates folders of data based on location, and on registered file type by querying the registry for registered application extensions.

segment.source: The MigUser.xml file migrates only the files with the specified file extensions.
segment.target: The MigUser.xml file migrates only the files with the specified file extensions.

segment.source: Close all applications before running either the ScanState or LoadState tools
segment.target: Close all applications before running either the ScanState or LoadState tools

segment.source: Although using the /vsc switch can allow the migration of many files that are open with another application it is a best practice to close all applications in order to ensure all files and settings migrate.
segment.target: Although using the /vsc switch can allow the migration of many files that are open with another application it is a best practice to close all applications in order to ensure all files and settings migrate.

segment.source: Without the /vsc or /c switch USMT will fail when it cannot migrate a file or setting.
segment.target: Without the /vsc or /c switch USMT will fail when it cannot migrate a file or setting.

segment.source: When you use the /c option USMT will ignore any files or settings that it cannot migrate and log an error each time.
segment.target: When you use the /c option USMT will ignore any files or settings that it cannot migrate and log an error each time.

segment.source: Log off after you run the LoadState
segment.target: Log off after you run the LoadState

segment.source: Some settings, such as fonts, wallpaper, and screensaver settings, will not take effect until the next time the user logs on.
segment.target: Some settings, such as fonts, wallpaper, and screensaver settings, will not take effect until the next time the user logs on.

segment.source: For this reason, you should log off after you run the LoadState tool.
segment.target: For this reason, you should log off after you run the LoadState tool.

segment.source: Managed environment
segment.target: Managed environment

segment.source: To create a managed environment, you can move all of the end user’s documents into My Documents (%CSIDLPERSONAL%).
segment.target: To create a managed environment, you can move all of the end user’s documents into My Documents (%CSIDLPERSONAL%).

segment.source: We recommend that you migrate files into the smallest-possible number of folders on the destination computer.
segment.target: We recommend that you migrate files into the smallest-possible number of folders on the destination computer.

segment.source: This will help you to clean up files on the destination computer, if the LoadState command fails before completion.
segment.target: This will help you to clean up files on the destination computer, if the LoadState command fails before completion.

segment.source: Chkdsk.exe
segment.target: Chkdsk.exe

segment.source: We recommend that you run Chkdsk.exe before running the ScanState and LoadState tools.
segment.target: We recommend that you run Chkdsk.exe before running the ScanState and LoadState tools.

segment.source: Chkdsk.exe creates a status report for a hard disk drive and lists and corrects common errors.
segment.target: Chkdsk.exe creates a status report for a hard disk drive and lists and corrects common errors.

segment.source: For more information about the Chkdsk.exe tool, see Chkdsk.
segment.target: For more information about the Chkdsk.exe tool, see Chkdsk.

segment.source: Migrate in groups
segment.target: Migrate in groups

segment.source: If you decide to perform the migration while users are using the network, it is best to migrate user accounts in groups.
segment.target: If you decide to perform the migration while users are using the network, it is best to migrate user accounts in groups.

segment.source: To minimize the impact on network performance, determine the size of the groups based on the size of each user account.
segment.target: To minimize the impact on network performance, determine the size of the groups based on the size of each user account.

segment.source: Migrating in phases also allows you to make sure each phase is successful before starting the next phase.
segment.target: Migrating in phases also allows you to make sure each phase is successful before starting the next phase.

segment.source: Using this method, you can make any necessary modifications to your plan between groups.
segment.target: Using this method, you can make any necessary modifications to your plan between groups.

segment.source: Security Best Practices
segment.target: Security Best Practices

segment.source: As the authorized administrator, it is your responsibility to protect the privacy of the users and maintain security during and after the migration.
segment.target: As the authorized administrator, it is your responsibility to protect the privacy of the users and maintain security during and after the migration.

segment.source: In particular, you must consider the following issues:
segment.target: In particular, you must consider the following issues:

segment.source: Encrypting File System (EFS)
segment.target: Encrypting File System (EFS)

segment.source: Take extreme caution when migrating encrypted files, because the end user does not need to be logged on to capture the user state.
segment.target: Take extreme caution when migrating encrypted files, because the end user does not need to be logged on to capture the user state.

segment.source: By default, USMT fails if an encrypted file is found.
segment.target: By default, USMT fails if an encrypted file is found.

segment.source: For more information about EFS best practices, see this article in the Microsoft Knowledge Base.
segment.target: For more information about EFS best practices, see this article in the Microsoft Knowledge Base.

segment.source: For specific instructions about EFS best practices, see Migrate EFS Files and Certificates.
segment.target: For specific instructions about EFS best practices, see Migrate EFS Files and Certificates.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: If you migrate an encrypted file without also migrating the certificate, end users will not be able to access the file after the migration.
segment.target: If you migrate an encrypted file without also migrating the certificate, end users will not be able to access the file after the migration.

segment.source: Encrypt the store
segment.target: Encrypt the store

segment.source: Consider using the /encrypt option with the ScanState command and the /decrypt option with the LoadState command.
segment.target: Consider using the /encrypt option with the ScanState command and the /decrypt option with the LoadState command.

segment.source: However, use extreme caution with this set of options, because anyone who has access to the ScanState command-line script also has access to the encryption key.
segment.target: However, use extreme caution with this set of options, because anyone who has access to the ScanState command-line script also has access to the encryption key.

segment.source: Virus Scan
segment.target: Virus Scan

segment.source: We recommend that you scan both the source and destination computers for viruses before running USMT.
segment.target: We recommend that you scan both the source and destination computers for viruses before running USMT.

segment.source: In addition, you should scan the destination computer image.
segment.target: In addition, you should scan the destination computer image.

segment.source: To help protect data from viruses, we strongly recommend running an antivirus utility before migration.
segment.target: To help protect data from viruses, we strongly recommend running an antivirus utility before migration.

segment.source: Maintain security of the file server and the deployment server
segment.target: Maintain security of the file server and the deployment server

segment.source: We recommend that you manage the security of the file and deployment servers.
segment.target: We recommend that you manage the security of the file and deployment servers.

segment.source: It is important to make sure that the file server where you save the store is secure.
segment.target: It is important to make sure that the file server where you save the store is secure.

segment.source: You must also secure the deployment server, to ensure that the user data that is in the log files is not exposed.
segment.target: You must also secure the deployment server, to ensure that the user data that is in the log files is not exposed.

segment.source: We also recommend that you only transmit data over a secure Internet connection, such as a virtual private network.
segment.target: We also recommend that you only transmit data over a secure Internet connection, such as a virtual private network.

segment.source: For more information about network security, see Microsoft Security Compliance Manager.
segment.target: For more information about network security, see Microsoft Security Compliance Manager.

segment.source: Password Migration
segment.target: Password Migration

segment.source: To ensure the privacy of the end users, USMT does not migrate passwords, including those for applications such as Windows Live™ Mail, Microsoft Internet Explorer®, as well as Remote Access Service (RAS) connections and mapped network drives.
segment.target: To ensure the privacy of the end users, USMT does not migrate passwords, including those for applications such as Windows Live™ Mail, Microsoft Internet Explorer®, as well as Remote Access Service (RAS) connections and mapped network drives.

segment.source: It is important to make sure that end users know their passwords.
segment.target: It is important to make sure that end users know their passwords.

segment.source: Local Account Creation
segment.target: Local Account Creation

segment.source: Before you migrate local accounts, see the Migrating Local Accounts section in the Identify Users topic.
segment.target: Before you migrate local accounts, see the Migrating Local Accounts section in the Identify Users topic.

segment.source: XML File Best Practices
segment.target: XML File Best Practices

segment.source: Specify the same set of mig.xml files in both the ScanState and the LoadState tools
segment.target: Specify the same set of mig.xml files in both the ScanState and the LoadState tools

segment.source: If you used a particular set of mig.xml files in the ScanState tool, either called through the "/auto" option, or individually through the "/i" option, then you should use same option to call the exact same mig.xml files in the LoadState tool.
segment.target: If you used a particular set of mig.xml files in the ScanState tool, either called through the "/auto" option, or individually through the "/i" option, then you should use same option to call the exact same mig.xml files in the LoadState tool.

segment.source: The CustomFileName in the migration urlid should match the name of the file
segment.target: The CustomFileName in the migration urlid should match the name of the file

segment.source: Although it is not a requirement, it is good practice for CustomFileName to match the name of the file.
segment.target: Although it is not a requirement, it is good practice for CustomFileName to match the name of the file.

segment.source: For example, the following is from the MigApp.xml file:
segment.target: For example, the following is from the MigApp.xml file:

segment.source: TUse the XML Schema (MigXML.xsd) when authoring .xml files to validate synta
segment.target: TUse the XML Schema (MigXML.xsd) when authoring .xml files to validate synta

segment.source: The MigXML.xsd schema file should not be included on the command line or in any of the .xml files.
segment.target: The MigXML.xsd schema file should not be included on the command line or in any of the .xml files.

segment.source: Use the default migration XML files as models
segment.target: Use the default migration XML files as models

segment.source: To create a custom .xml file, you can use the migration .xml files as models to create your own.
segment.target: To create a custom .xml file, you can use the migration .xml files as models to create your own.

segment.source: If you need to migrate user data files, model your custom .xml file on MigUser.xml.
segment.target: If you need to migrate user data files, model your custom .xml file on MigUser.xml.

segment.source: To migrate application settings, model your custom .xml file on the MigApp.xml file.
segment.target: To migrate application settings, model your custom .xml file on the MigApp.xml file.

segment.source: Consider the impact on performance when using the context parameter
segment.target: Consider the impact on performance when using the context parameter

segment.source: Your migration performance can be affected when you use the context element with the component element; for example, as in when you want to encapsulate logical units of file- or path-based include and exclude rules.
segment.target: Your migration performance can be affected when you use the context element with the component element; for example, as in when you want to encapsulate logical units of file- or path-based include and exclude rules.

segment.source: In the User context, a rule is processed one time for each user on the system.
segment.target: In the User context, a rule is processed one time for each user on the system.

segment.source: In the System context, a rule is processed one time for the system.
segment.target: In the System context, a rule is processed one time for the system.

segment.source: In the UserAndSystem context, a rule is processed one time for each user on the system and one time for the system.
segment.target: In the UserAndSystem context, a rule is processed one time for each user on the system and one time for the system.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The number of times a rule is processed does not affect the number of times a file is migrated.
segment.target: The number of times a rule is processed does not affect the number of times a file is migrated.

segment.source: The USMT migration engine ensures that each file migrates only once.
segment.target: The USMT migration engine ensures that each file migrates only once.

segment.source: We recommend that you create a separate .xml file instead of adding your .xml code to one of the existing migration .xml files
segment.target: We recommend that you create a separate .xml file instead of adding your .xml code to one of the existing migration .xml files

segment.source: For example, if you have code that migrates the settings for an application, you should not just add the code to the MigApp.xml file.
segment.target: For example, if you have code that migrates the settings for an application, you should not just add the code to the MigApp.xml file.

segment.source: You should not create custom .xml files to alter the operating system settings that are migrated
segment.target: You should not create custom .xml files to alter the operating system settings that are migrated

segment.source: These settings are migrated by manifests and you cannot modify those files.
segment.target: These settings are migrated by manifests and you cannot modify those files.

segment.source: If you want to exclude certain operating system settings from the migration, you should create and modify a Config.xml file.
segment.target: If you want to exclude certain operating system settings from the migration, you should create and modify a Config.xml file.

segment.source: You can use the asterisk () wildcard character in any migration XML file that you create
segment.target: You can use the asterisk () wildcard character in any migration XML file that you create

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The question mark is not valid as a wildcard character in USMT .xml files.
segment.target: The question mark is not valid as a wildcard character in USMT .xml files.

segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: Migration Store Encryption
